titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Collection on Enslavement in Cuba MSS.569
titlestmt.author: Collection processed by Rachel Searcy

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2023-06-13T13:58:14

change.item: Item-level titles and descriptions were revised by Stacey Flatt, Nicole Greenhouse, Rachel Mahre, Anna Björnsson McCormick, Rachel Searcy, Aki Snyder, and Weatherly Stephan to correct inaccuracies, remove racist language, and contextualize collection

did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in Spanish, with some documents in English.
did.unittitle: Collection on Enslavement in Cuba
did.abstract: The time period covered by this collection was the final century of 400 years of Spanish colonization of the island of Cuba. Although Spain and Great Britain agreed to end the trade of enslaved people in Spanish colonies by 1820, an estimated one million enslaved Africans were brought to Cuba by Spanish colonists. Cuba formally ended its participation in the Transatlantic Slave Trade in 1867, and abolished the legal enslavement of people in 1886. Enslaved people endured family separation, harsh manual labor on sugar plantations and in sugar mills, and labor within an enslaver's household. Enslaved women were often victims of sexual assault and exploitation. From 1847-1874, hundreds of thousands of Chinese men were trafficked to Cuba as indentured laborers by the Spanish, French, British, and Americans. This collection consists of documents concerning slavery in Spanish-colonized Cuba between 1809 and 1898, and the infrastructure that supported Spanish and American planation owners at the expense of enslaved and indentured individuals. Materials include telegrams, contracts, identification papers, travel licenses, birth notices, marriage and baptism records, death and burial certificates, purchase and insurance documents, and manumission records documenting various aspects of enslavement in Cuba, including the economics of the Transatlantic Slave Trade, demographics of Cuban populations, England's abolition of slavery, the transportation of indentured Chinese laborers to Cuba, family relationships in the context of slavery, living and working conditions on sugar cane plantations, and manumission processes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of documents concerning slavery in Spanish-colonized Cuba between 1809 and 1898 and the infrastructure that supported Spanish and American planation owners at the expense of enslaved and indentured individuals. Materials include telegrams, contracts, identification papers, travel licenses, birth notices, marriage and baptism records, death and burial certificates, purchase and insurance documents, and manumission records documenting various aspects of enslavement in Cuba, including the economics of the Transatlantic Slave Trade, demographics of Cuban populations, England's abolition of slavery, the transportation of indentured Chinese laborers to Cuba, family relationships in the context of slavery, living and working conditions on sugar cane plantations, and manumission processes.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection, which were created in 1809-1898 range, are in the public domain. Permission to publish or reproduce is not required.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials in this collection were purchased from bookseller Kevin Jackson by Timothy V. Johnson, NYU Librarian for Africana Studies, Anthropology and Food Studies in December 2014; original provenance is unknown. The collection was transferred to the Fales Library and Special Collections in 2017. The accession number associated with this purchase is 2019.010.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Collection on Enslavement in Cuba; MSS 569; box number; folder number or item identifier; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Documents with brittle paper were rehoused to prevent immediate loss and documents with ink damage were housed in mylar with paper backing for additional support. Materials were described on the collection-level. The folder-level inventory was created by the collection's seller and modified by an archivist to remove derogatory terms and contextual details not relevant to the items.

In August 2022, narrative description and individual folder titles were edited to employ the recommendations in P. Gabrielle Foreman's community-sourced document "Writing About Slavery/Teaching About Slavery: This Might Help," as well as the Archives for Black Lives in Philadelphia's Anti-Racist Description Resources. These item-level titles and descriptions were written by non-Spanish language speakers who are not experts in the history of enslavement in Spanish-colonized Cuba. Some spellings are approximate. Future changes to correct inaccuracies or inappropriate language are anticipated.
Researchers can access previous versions of the finding aid in our GitHub repository at https://github.com/NYULibraries/findingaids_eads/commits/master/fales/mss_569.xml.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Folder 1 in the inventory, a grouping of 80 documents concerning a case of five enslaved people at a sugar mill who killed a man they believed to be the Governor General of Cuba, was removed from the collection and cataloged separately as HV6535.C9 C66 1842.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the seller.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Iron gall ink present in many documents in the collection has caused paper loss. Some documents are partially legible as a result.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The time period covered by this collection was the final century of 400 years of Spanish colonization of the island of Cuba. Although Spain and Great Britain agreed to end the trade of enslaved people in Spanish colonies by 1820, an estimated one million enslaved Africans were brought to Cuba by Spanish colonists. Cuba formally ended its participation in the Transatlantic Slave Trade in 1867, and abolished the legal enslavement of people in 1886. Enslaved people endured family separation, harsh manual labor on sugar plantations and in sugar mills, and labor within an enslaver's household. Enslaved women were often victims of sexual assault and exploitation. From 1847-1874, hundreds of thousands of Chinese men were trafficked to Cuba as indentured laborers by the Spanish, French, British, and Americans. In port cities like Hong Kong and Macao, Chinese men were kidnapped or coerced into signing contracts by enslavers posing as recruitment agents. Although the contracts offered freedom after eight years, this freedom was not enforced, and the laborers often died before the term ended due to malnourishment and abusive conditions.

did.unittitle: Cuban Manuscript Concerning the Incarceration of Self-Liberated Cimarrones
Cuban Telegram Regarding Human Trafficking and Slavery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Cuban telegram regarding human trafficking and slavery was sent to Lieutenant Governor General Cardenas.

did.unittitle: Death Certificate for Estanislao, an Enslaved Chinese Man

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: According to the death certificate, Estanislao died at Charity Hospital of San Felipe y Santiago.

did.unittitle: Insurance Certificate for a Person Enslaved by Joaquin Soler

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This certificate, created by La Protectora Compania General Cubana de Seguros Mutuos Sobre la Vida de Esclavos, includes information such as the price of the insurance, the corresponding legal articles, and the signature of the insurance director. It does not appear to include the name of the enslaved person.

did.unittitle: Certificates of Burial for a Fetus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These certificates of burial were issued by the Church of the Holy Spirit and the Church of Monserrate in Havana. They do not appear to list the name of the deceased, whose mother was an enslaved person.

did.unittitle: Document Summarizing Enslaved Person Expenditures
La Providencia Insurance Document for an Enslaved Person in Havana
Document of Marriage Between Enslaved People
Sobre Desobediencia Negro Cargador de Cadaveres
Identity Paper for Dominga

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dominga was a 21 year old enslaved woman.

Manumission Document for Lelicia Frenyo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Insurance receipt issued in Havana by the Director General to D. Franco Equileor regarding the purchase of an enslaved person.

scopecontent.p: Receipt for payment of La Providencia insurance purchased by enslaver Francisco Munso.

did.unittitle: Identification Paper for Guillermo Ceta

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Government identification paper permitting the travel of Guillermo Ceta, a man enslaved by Cristobal Alonzo of La Habana, to Pueblo.

did.unittitle: Memo on the Receipt of Muzzles in Cienfuegos

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Short note describing the receipt of muzzles in Cienfuegos, from Habana .

did.unittitle: Marriage Contract between Two Enslaved People
Telegram to Captain Pral from Francisco F. de la Regeas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Telegram sent to Captain Pral in Habana from Francisco F. de la Regeas concerning legal statues in Santo Domingo.

did.unittitle: Marriage Contract between Two Enslaved People
La Providencia Receipt for Insurance of Enslaved People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Receipt for payment of La Providencia insurance purchased by enslaver Ambrosio M. Rendon.

did.unittitle: Marriage Contract between Two Emancipated People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marriage contract between Francisco Andrade and Moxcelenia (?) Avinev, both free people.

did.unittitle: Telegram Concerning Enslavement from Ramon Menduinal
Documents Regarding the Death and Burial of Felix

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Felix, a criollo man enslaved by Juan Delgado, drowned in a well in 1854. Felix was 30 years old.

did.unittitle: Correspondence regarding the grave of Felix

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Felix, a criollo man enslaved by Juan Delgado, drowned in a well in 1854. Felix was 30 years old.

did.unittitle: Document Referencing the Emancipation of Marmelita
Birth Notice of Jose
Certificate of Indenture for Chinese Laborer Anselmo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This document states that Anselmo, a 23-year-old laborer from China, was contracted to work in a quarry for eight years and for Carmen Herrera for an equal amount of time.

did.unittitle: Contract Enslaving Franc Real

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: La Comision Poblacion Blanca contract regarding Franc Real, a 20 year old man from Palma, Spain, who was enslaved by Aburo S.

did.unittitle: Contract Enslaving Justo Asioca

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tenencia de Gobierno de Guanajay contract regarding Justo Asioca, a 28 year old Chinese man who was enslaved by Andres Fin.

did.unittitle: Contract Enslaving Enreterio San Achin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tenencia de Gobierno de Guanajay contract regarding Enreterio San Achin, a 28 year old Chinese man who was enslaved by Paulino Sigarreta.

did.unittitle: Document of the Death and burial of Domingo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: According to the document, Domingo was an enslaved Chinese man.

did.unittitle: Contract Enslaving Julien Aguat

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gobierno Politico de la Habana contract regarding Julien Aguat, a 28 year old Chinese man who was enslaved by Manuel Dorado.

did.unittitle: Identification Document for Leopoldo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gobierno Politico de la Habana identification document regarding Leopoldo, a 24 year old Chinese man who was enslaved by B. Pereda.

did.unittitle: Contract Enslaving nine Spanish people

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Real Junta de Fomento de la Isla de Cuba contract regarding nine Spanish people who were enslaved by Saypa Hernandez: Jose Hernandez, his wife Bernarda, Luyor, Antonio, Maxie, Gregorio, Novento Luis Garcia, Art Calaturo Luyo, and Salvatore Inan Reiz.

did.unittitle: Document Regarding Enslaved People Who Escaped from a Ship

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jerónimo Valdés (1784–1855) was a Spanish military figure and administrator. Born in Villarín, in Asturias, he participated in the battle of Ayacucho (1824), which was a defeat for the Spanish. He served as Viceroy of Navarre from 1833 to 1834 and also served as Minister of War. He fought on the Liberal (Isabeline) side in the First Carlist War. Valdés lost the Battle of Artaza (April 22, 1835). Valdés signed the Lord Eliot Convention soon after, regulating the treatment of prisoners during that war. He later served as captain-general of Valencia, and of Galicia, and served as governor of Cuba from 1841 to September 1843.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This printed memo was issued by the Captain General of Cuba, Geronimo Valdes. It accounts that there was an illegal disembarkation of escaped enslaved people who hid in a farm near Matanzas. Valdes also states that this information was passed on by the British.

did.unittitle: Documentation Regarding Sale of the La Constancia Sugar Mill and List of 72 Enslaved People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: List of people enslaved by Yugo la Costancia: Bernardo of Ganga (now known as Sierra Leone); Fernando; José Maria; Domingo; José Maria; Antonio; Ysidro; Ramon; Miguel; Alesandro; Nicolas; Juan Banta(?); Pablo; Martin; José de la Luz; Julian; Pascual; José de Jesus; Juaquin of Minia; Manuel; Caruelo of Macua; Gerbasio; Facundo(?); Rafael of Congo; Domingo; Antonio Peria; Reniger from Criullo; Luis; Cristobal; Rogue; Eusebio (?); José del Rosario; Juan; Sernan of Criullo; Abraham; Loreto; Juaquin; Candelario; Salustiano; Miguel; [illegible name] of Mata; Eugenia; Fernando; G~; Antonio; Hilario; Regino; Carlos; Juliana of Ganga (now known as Sierra Leone); Josefa; Antonia; Paula; Matilde; Maria de Jesus of Conga; Vitoria of Mina; A~; Catalina; Vicenta of Carabali; Pasilia of Criolla; Barbara; Ynés; Petrona; [illegible name]; Ana Ma; Luisa; Eulogia; Marcelina of Criolla; Lacarido; Ynes, Rosa.

did.unittitle: Priest's Formal Declaration of Baptism of a Freed Person
Contract in Guanajay between Felis Banbul and Laborer Vicente Vega from China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Government Department of Guanajay, Felis Banbul, entered into a contract with 28 year old laborer Vicente Vega from Canton (China) for two years. According to the contract, Vega was to be paid a salary of eight pesos.

did.unittitle: Cuban License Giving Permission for Four Congolese Enslaved People to Travel by Train

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Enslaved people listed are: Petro from Criolla; Jose Lucumi; Cristobal from Ganga (now known as Sierra Leone); and Florence from Congo. Document is signed by Governor Leopold O'Donnell.

did.unittitle: Cuban License Giving Permission for 36 Enslaved People to Travel by Train

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cuban license to travel freely by train to work on a sugar plantation. Enslaved people include: Antonio from Criollo; Jerman; Fran; Camilo; Hepomuceno; Cirito; Domingo; Polomo; Francisco; Prospero from Criolla; Isidro; Miguel from Ganga (now known as Sierra Leone); Matilde; Canuta; Ynes; [illegible name]; [illegible name]; Serefina; Ma Fran; Dominga; Joaquina from Ganga (now known as Sierra Leone); M. de la Cruz; Andrea; Ignasia; Francisca from Carabali; Damiana; Gregoria from Conga; and Julia. Document is signed by Governor Leopoldo O'Donnell.

did.unittitle: Document from Spanish Officials to Cuban Government Regarding Fine for Enslavers of Escaped Enslaved People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Document was written in Aranjuez, Spain during the Presidencia del Consejo de Ministerio de Ultramar and addressed to the Captain General of Cuba Domingo Dulce y Garay, who signed it upon receipt in Havana. The document discusses a fine of 30 pesos for owners of escaped enslaved people.

did.unittitle: Labor Contract Issued for Felipe Alvansa Lorano and Dolores Cantillo
Labor Contract issued for 28 Enslaved People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Enslaved people include A. Hareia Perez, Ignacio Perez Martin, Cabrera de la Cairr, Domingo Lopes de Soper, Juan Medina, Augustin Martin Sandia, Foreana Guerra Hermand, Algio Acona, Juan Remedia Rodrig, Juan Delgado Pino, Nicolas Sanchez, Juan Ventura, Jore Rodrig, Jore Gabriel Ortega, Clemente Perez Hernand, Ynidao Entrella Bentigra, Lucious de la Coneff Eponiso, Juan de la C. Bello, Augustus de la C. Bello, Jore Hernandez, Portifo Luis Sanchez, Perez Martin, Viciente Diaz, Franco Perez, Mateo Carpio, Jore Manuel Remedio, and Geronimo Hernand.

did.unittitle: Identity Paper for Luis
Neighborhood News Bulletin on a Freedperson who was Subsequently robbed
Baptismal Declaration for Luis from Congo and Ricardo from Macau, Enslaved by Alejandro de Castro
Birth declaration for Miguel Pripo [sp?], Born to Freewoman Oqueda Valdes
Declaration Attesting that Juan Nacion Lucunne [sp?] Enslaved by Dr. Pedro Martin Prabell and his Godfather Alejo was Enslaved by Dr. Jose Calasano Bilardebo
Birth Notice for the Child of Two Enslaved people, Nestor and Ramona

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The document indicates that the father, Nestor, is from the Congo and the mother, Ramona, is from Ganga (now known as Sierra-Leone).

did.unittitle: Request to Have a Newborn Child of an Enslaved Woman and Unnamed Man Baptized.
Statement of baptism for a Congolese enslaved person who belongs to the "Commission of the Railroad"
Manuscript Concerning the Capture of Escaped Enslaved People

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The document concerns the escape and capture of Luis, an enslaved person from the Congo, and Inastasio, another enslaved person. Their enslaver was Dolores Pebles de Pimienta.

did.unittitle: Declaration that the Sacred Sacrement is Being Given to a Enslaved Native Person

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The enslaved person is described as criollo.

did.unittitle: Birth Notice for the Child of an Enslaved Mother
Birth Notice for Merced Candelaria

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This document describes the birth of Merced Candelaria on February 2, 1847. Merced's parents were both enslaved people.

did.unittitle: Statement on Martina Abasi of Carabali

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martina Abasi, a free woman of color, is identified as the godmother of emancipated people.

did.unittitle: Birth Notice of the Child of Juana Albarez

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note on the birth of the child of Juana Albarez, a free woman of color, on All Saints Day. The child is the grandchild of Antonio Albarez and Rosalia Carrora, also free people of color, and the godchild of Anselmo Garcia and Sabel Angel, both identified as criollo. The father is unknown.

did.unittitle: Birth Notice of Maria Manuela

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note on the birth of Maria Manuela, January 1877, to Emilia Dias (born Guines), maternal grandmother Eusebia Dias, and godmother Dominga Valdes.

did.unittitle: Baptism Notice of Pastoria

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notice of the baptism of Pastoria, a criolla child born on March 30, 1862 into enslavement. She is the daughter of Polonia, a criolla woman, and an unknown father. Both parents were enslaved by Ygnacio do Oildosola. The godmother of the child is Ascunsion, a criolla woman enslaved by Josefa de Osmal.

did.unittitle: Birth Notice of Serafin Usvano de Jesus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notice of the birth of Serafin Usvano de Jesus on May 25, 1862 in Habana. A signed statement follows declaring that José Congo, an emancipated Congolese person, the godchild of an enslaved person, has been in the custody of Colonel D. Antonio Garcia Rizo since seventeen years of age.

did.unittitle: Neighborhood News Bulletin Describing a Fight

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript news bulletin discussing a fight between two enslaved persons from different enslavers.

did.unittitle: Birth Notice of Laurecia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notice of the birth of Laurencia, daughter of Nicenta, a criolla woman, and an unknown father who was enslaved by J. Godinez. The child's godmother is Maria Mincheta, a criolla woman enslaved by Sofia Perran.

did.unittitle: Manuscript Concerning Two Enslaved People Not Listed on Ship Manifest

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript concerning two enslaved people named Ines and Raimunda not listed on ship manifest.

did.unittitle: Birth Notice of Arnalda

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notice of the birth of Arnalda, a criolla girl. Arnalda is the daughter of Nestor from the Congo and Ramona from Ganga (now known as Sierra Leone), both enslaved by Leon de Martiarte. Her godmother is Mariane.

did.unittitle: Manuscript Concerning an Emancipated Congolese Person Pursued by Law Enforcement
Emancipation Document

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Emancipation document for five people, named: Guadalupe, Silvestre, Ricardo, Ruperto, and Eduardo.

did.unittitle: Manumission Document for Higinio Guillermo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manumission document for Higinio Guillermo, a boy in Habana born to an enslaved woman named Juana Paula. Higinio Guillermo's father is not named.

did.unittitle: Death Certificate for Domingo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Death certificate for Domingo, a man described as an escaped enslaved person originally from Asia. Domingo died at the Hospital de Caridad de San Felipe y Santiago.

did.unittitle: Emancipation Document

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Emancipation document for five people, named: Niealasa, Valentin, Gregoria, Luisa, and Maltida. The document also lists Matilda's daughter Perfecta.

did.unittitle: Notice that an Emancipated Man was seen in a Havana Warehouse
Birth Notice of Angel
Birth Notice of Maria Micaela Garcia
Birth Notice of Fran. and Beatriz
Birth Notice of Maria Ca[mdel]aria
Birth Notice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This document is a birth notice of a child who was likely enslaved.
